learning_outcomes.description: Conduct detailed autopsies, identify pathological processes, and analyse samples to diagnose diseases in the core companion and farm animals adhering to principles of biosecurity and public health.

Review disease mechanisms and significance, develop diagnostic plans, create differential diagnosis lists, and provide advice on disease management for individuals and groups. Use both intuitive and analytical clinical reasoning strategies alongside foundational pathophysiological principles for clinical and autopsy case workups.

Interpret clinical pathology results while recognising analytical limitations and sources of error, selecting appropriate diagnostic tests considering proper biosecurity principles throughout the diagnostic process. Develop differential diagnoses as well as identifying and prioritising problems, then integrate clinical and laboratory results to reach a diagnosis. Understand key laboratory workflows and how pre-analytical and analytical factors influence result quality.

Communicate effectively about diagnostic pathology. Maintain professionalism in interactions and actively engage in feedback to assess strengths, address weaknesses, and develop skills for professional readiness.

assessments.task_description:
The 3 week diagnostic pathology rotation is predominantly oriented around clinical cases presented to Veterinary Laboratory Services (VLS). Students will become competent with in-house clinical pathology analysers, perform and interpret clinical pathology tests (e.g. haematology, biochemistry, urinalysis), and manage clinical autopsy cases. Students will receive formative feedback throughout the rotation. 

Details of shift start and end times and after hours duty rosters can be found on the VETS5020 course Blackboard site prior to the start of each rotation.

(1) Diagnostic Pathology Performance Assessment

The diagnostic pathologists will provide a minimum of THREE (3) student performance feedback forms during the rotation. The marking rubric is available on the VETS5020 course Blackboard site.

Completion of the performance assessment includes submission of the Student Pathology Report.

Students MUST provide a written report for all autopsies. On completion, the report must be emailed by no later than 10am the next business day to the supervising pathologist for review. The supervising pathologist may require multiple editorial changes to the report to achieve a satisfactory final outcome. The final version must then be uploaded to the relevant student group on the VETS5020 course Blackboard site.

Case Log Data Upload

Information (the case log data) pertinent to every case must be uploaded to the spreadsheet provided to each student group and emailed to the supervising pathologist by 10am of the next business day.

The final version of the student pathology report MUST be uploaded to the corresponding group the student belongs to in the VETS5020 Blackboard site.

The Performance Feedback Form will comprise five (5) equally weighted categories (Knowledge base; Clinical skills; Technical skills; Professional skills, and Communication). Each category has three performance marks (0/Does not meet standard; 1/Meets standard; 2/Exceeds standard). The rubric has a total of 10 possible marks. An average of all Diagnostic Pathology Performance Assessment marks is calculated at the end of the rotation. 

(2) Direct Observation of Procedural Skills (DOPS)

During the Diagnostic Rotation, students must complete a minimum of TWO (2) DOPS.

  1. One small animal autopsy - dog or cat
  2. Second autopsy - dog, cat, large animal, wildlife or exotic

Instructions for the various procedures and their assessment rubrics are available in My Knowledge Map (MKM). Students will receive feedback and an overall rating on the various composite skills within the DOPS. Each skill must be performed to an overall assessment of "Meets Standard and is Day-One Ready" in order to pass this assessment task.

(3) Diagnostic Pathology Skills

During the rotation, students will be assessed on the following diagnostic pathology skills:

  1. Removal of a brain with a handsaw (any species)
  2. Dissection of the heart using UQ standard methodology
  3. Presentation of a case at pathology gross rounds, emphasising case history and lesion description.
  4. Collection of a histopathology or other diagnostic sample (bacteriology, virology, toxicology, parasitology)
  5. Demonstrated preparation of a sample for cytological assessment (fine needle aspirate, tissue smear, squash prep etc. with Diff-Quik or Giemsa staining)

These compound skills are specific to VETS5020 and must be signed off by a pathologist/tutor during the rotation. Completion of these items will be graded as Pass/Fail.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Use of Artificial Intelligence

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
This is a structured, case-based cytology learning experience. Students will have access to 15 scanned (online) cytology slides. In each week of the diagnostic pathology rotation, students are expected to spend three hours working independently to review FIVE (5) slides. To facilitate systematic appraisal, a structured template will be available on the VETS5020 course Blackboard site. In Week 3 of the rotation, all 15 slides will be reviewed during a three hour tutorial (face to face and Zoom) in which students may ask questions and extend their understanding of cytological pathology.

Students must submit, to the VETS5020 course Blackboard site, a completed template for each of the 15 slides prior to the final week tutorial. All constituent components of the template must be adequately addressed, but a diagnosis is NOT required. The objective of this task is to emphasise the necessity of a systematic approach to reviewing cytology. 

The assessment is Pass/Fail, and therefore a hurdle. To pass this hurdle, all 15 templates must be graded as satisfactory. Templates NOT graded as satisfactory will be returned for further work and then resubmitted.

assessments.task_description:
The Capstone Examination will provide a comprehensive evaluation of students’ clinical problem-solving skills, regardless of species or discipline.

The exam assesses core knowledge, clinical reasoning, and the ability to diagnose and manage conditions commonly encountered during the first year of practice. The exam will include contributions from the following courses: VETS5015, VETS5020, VETS5024, VETS5028, VETS5029, and VETS5030.

Exam Structure

  • Two parts, each containing 84 multiple-choice (MCQ) questions
  • Each part will take approximately two hours
  • Questions from each course will be weighted according to the course’s unit value

For sample questions, exam duration details, and the distribution of questions per section, please refer to your course Blackboard site.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
